message: [maven-release-plugin] prepare release tripleplay-2.0.5

Merge pull request #74 from guillerodriguez/pixel_coords

Merge pull request #75 from guillerodriguez/scroller

Make Scroller pixel-aware when using layer translation for clipping.
Make Scroller pixel-aware when using layer translation for clipping.
Added test for improved pixel coordinate handling.

Improve our alignment to physical pixel boundaries.

Previously we aligned elements to integral logical pixel boundaries, and relied
on the ratio between logical and physical pixels to be integral. This is no
longer the case in the wild world of zillions of screen sizes and densities.

Our new approach is to leave logical position/size alone until validation, at
which point we ensure that our boundaries (top, left, bottom, right) fall on
integral physical pixels and then translate those back to an updated logical
position and size which are used when laying out deeper children.

Added AUTHORS file.

Re-headered everything with copyright assigned to authors (since OOO is no
longer a legal entity), and with an updated end year.

setLocation(): round coords instead of truncating.

setLocation(): round coords instead of truncating.

This avoids visual artifacts on devices with non-integer
scaling factors.

Fix previous commit.

Pointer events are already in screen coordinates, and in any case
screen cordinates are not what we want here. Instead, use the "local"
event coordinates (translated to the hit layer's coordinate space).

Translate pointer event coordinates to screen coordinates.

This fixes the case for layers that have transforms applied

Fix ordering issue in set.

We need to call removeFromParent before we assign the new child as the contents
of the box because *we* might be the old parent.

In most cases this won't ever happen because the public set() checks if we're
adding the same element to the box; but in the transition code (where we fade
or flip a new child into the box), we "pre-add" a child, then transition to
that child during a time when the old and new children are both parented by the
box, and finally we "add" the new child, which causes it to be removed from its
old parent, which in this case is the current box.

This also more closely matches Elements, which calls removeFromParent, then
adds new children to its internal tracking array, then calls didAdd.
Reorg a bit to keep cuddling code together.

The LWJGL TPPlatform only works with LWJGL2.
Fix layer depth funny business, other tidying.

Added ScreenSpace.bottom().

When you want to blow away all screens, it's best to popTo(bottom) and then
replace the bottom screen. That results in sane transitions for everyone
involved.

Just pass the Game to the Screen ctor.

You have to have the game in the super ctor anyway because you need to save it
and return it in your own game() override, and we're not saving you from
calling the super ctor because we needed the Platform.
Better docs for Timer.
Some Bag enhancements.

Avoid double reporting entities.

When we add a new system, we want to tell it about all "already added"
entities, but we were telling it about all entities, even those that were
themselves just added and which were about to be reported to all systems.

Now we only tell new systems about existing entities, and then we tell all
systems (including the newly added systems) about new entities.

Nix ValueLabel use in demo.

Deprecated ValueLabel. Added ValueView ctor to Label.

Label now already does what ValueLabel does, with more flexibility (view
bindText). So I added a ValueView ctor to Label (and made it take any type of
value, which will be toString-ed), which makes Label as easy to use as
ValueLabel.

A bit of LayoutData revampery, to simplify.

Previously LayoutData had three jobs:

1. Track any resolved style or ephemeral data which is needed to layout a
widget. This stuff is only needed for layout, so we'd resolve it, compute
preferred size, do the layout, then throw it away. That way we're not keeping
around a bunch of crap for every single widget during normal operation.

2. Use the resolved data to compute widget's preferred size, via
LayoutData.computeSize().

3. Use the resolved data to lay the widget out, via LayoutData.layout().

But this sucked when you just wanted to make a minor tweak to computeSize() or
layout() based on some non-ephemeral state. You had to create a special
subclass of LayoutData just to hold the code that really should have been in
the Element subclass instead.

There was also some fiddly shenanigans with BaseLayoutData and LayoutData for
probably stupid reasons that have long since been forgotten.

Now there's just one LayoutData class, which defines two ("NOOP" by default)
methods: computeSize() and layout(), and two Element methods (of the same name)
which delegate to the LayoutData methods by default.

In cases where a simple tweak is needed (Box, Composite, GlyphWidget,
ImageButton), no custom LayoutData class is needed at all. The Element
subclasses just override the methods that would have delegated to LayoutData
and do the right thing right there. Simple!

In one case (Scroller), ScrollerLayoutData is used to track some ephemeral
data, but we still handle the computeSize() and layout() in Scroller's methods
rather than ScrollerLayoutData's methods (mainly because we're specializing
Composite/Container, which now do their layout in Element.layout).

In a few other cases (TextWigdet, Slider), we still do things the "old" way,
where TextWidgetLayoutData and SliderLayoutData implement computeSize() and
layout() directly, because they resolve a shit ton of layout data and it's nice
to be able to access that stuff directly via the this pointer.

I was tempted to convert everything to "Scroller"-style where all LayoutData
subclasses were just structs that held extra data and all custom logic went
into the Element subclass, but I needed to preserve the old LayoutData methods
and behavior for all the custom code out in the wild that has created its own
LayoutData subclass. So since that has to live on, I might as well use it in
the few cases where it's tidier.

Element can now track bindings to reactive values.

This allows the element to establish a connection when it is added to a UI
hierarchy and dispose of it when it is removed. Doing so relieves the caller of
managing the lifetime of the connection themselves, which is error-prone and
leaky.

Often the lifetime of a reactive value and a UI element that displays it do not
coincide, and the reactive value long outlives the element, which results in
leaks if special care is not taken to ensure that connections are closed when
the element goes away. This bind mechanism makes that easy to do, syntactically
concise, and cheaper than creating a Closeable.Set and binding it to the
element's hierarchy signal (which was the only general purpose way to do this
before this change).

Add setText/setIcon.

Sometimes you want to set these things fluently, after the fact.

Only bind to our value when we're added to the UI.

This allows us to display values which outlive our UI without worrying that
garbage views will keep listening and responding to value changes.

Make our top-level screen absorb hits.

This is necessary for the untrans listener to work in all circumstances.
Previously we were relying on a UI to be catching all events at some level, but
we won't always have a UI, or we may also have a UI with no interactive bits.

now, so I'm going to live with yet another incarnation of these same ideas
(c.f. ScreenStack, ScreenSpace).

Nix some debug logging.

Introduced wasValidated(). Blah.

We can't just hook layout() because then we emit the _validated signal *before*
we mark the Root as validated. So if the validated signal results in any
changes being made to the UI, those won't trigger a new validation cycle as
they should.

So we have to have a wasValidated() hook which is called after validated is set
to true, so that we can invalidate in wasValidated. Messy.
Fixed wake issue, added asserts, stubbed IN/OUT.

Emit validated after layout(), not validate().

The latter is called every frame to check whether we need validation, the
former is called only when we actually need validation.
A bit of DWIM wrt the first frame of a transition.

New navigation mechanism: ScreenSpace.

This is a bit like ScreenStack, but different enough to not really benefit from
sharing code. A ScreenSpace provides an infinite 2D grid metaphor, where new
screens slide in from a direction, and the user then goes "back" by sliding the
current screen back in the direction from whence it came.

Care has been taken to allow a ScreenSpace to interact comfortably with screens
that scroll (via Flicker). So you can, for example, scroll a new screen UP into
view, then then allow the user to continue scrolling up to see the whole
scrolled screen. But if they scroll DOWN while looking at the top of the
screen, this initiates an untransition gesture which takes them back to the
previous screen.

Naturally when you transition screens orthogonally to the main scroll direction
(slide new screen in LEFT and then scroll up and down), things work nicely as
well.

This is not yet totally complete. There are some non-space transitions to be
implemented (IN/OUT which will zoom and cross fade to simulate going INto our
OUT of the plane, and FLIP, which will work like ScreenStack's flip). These
non-space transitions will not afford user initiated untransition gestures, so
in those cases the app will have to provide back buttons, as usual. But it's
nice to have the option to include non-spatial transitions where they make
sense.

I'm also going to support a horizontally scrolled, but snapped to contents,
style UI screen where the screen supports an arbitrary number of UI Roots each
of which is laid out vertically, and the user can use sliding gestures to go
left and right between them. Naturally, this will be set up so that if you want
you can have a leftward slide from the left-most column initiate an
untransition to the previous screen if that's how these screens came in, or you
can transition vertically into a left/right navigable screen, and have the user
go UP to get out of it (which is nice because they can use UP regardless of
which column they're in).

https://github.com/threerings/tripleplay/issues/47

The suggested fix would work but would also make things more confusing. The setSize call in
Preloader would have no effect because ImageLayer takes it's size from the image by default.

So instead, change the class hierarchy to reflect what Preloaded and Loader really have in common,

Add a comment about a limitation of the frame stepping in Movie.

Fix a bug in flump Movie where when a new symbol appeared on a keyframe, it didn't reset it.

Specifically, in flash, removing a symbol, then adding it again later, will always reset that symbol to the start of its own timeline, so flump should do this too. Making the symbol invisible but leaving it on the timeline, however, will NOT reset it.

Fix bug in handling the end-of-movie in MoviePlayer.PlayAnimation

In particular, it wasn't recognizing when the movie had been stepped through all the way to the end, was allowing the movie to loop around and play its first frame before noticing it was ready to be removed.

Simpler. Courtesy of Ray.
Missed a spot.

Vastly simplified animation completion.

Firstly, the logic was scattered all over the damned place and the copies
weren't consistent. AnimGroup was checking canceled, but Animation wasn't. The
duplication is now gone and the logic is necessarily consistent because it only
exists once.

I changed the canceled check to cause things to blow up. Either you cancel()
your animations or you complete() them. You don't mix and match. There's no way
we can do anything reasonable in such circumstances, so we disallow it.

The makeComplete() (nee complete()) method is now documented as being
idempotent so that we can now simply go through the whole animation chain and
mark every animation is complete whether or not it has been previously
processed.

If a layer is in an animation chain multiple times, like:

  moveTo(layerA, pointA).then.moveTo(layerA, pointB)

and the first animation has already completed before complete() is called, then
the first animation will move layerA to pointA during the completion process,
but the second animation will move layerA to pointB immediately afterwards, so
aside from a miniscule amount of extra effort (possibly offset by vastly
simpler completion logic) there will be no visible funny business. Everything
will end up where it should be were the animation chain allowed to complete
normally.

It is possible that a totally separate animation chain was queued up to
manipulate a layer after the first one completed, but then that first one went
on to do other things and was complete()d later, thereby stepping on the toes
of the second spawned animation chain. But arguably you should be completing
all animation chains in that case and completing them in the order that they
were spawned, so you should still be OK. Though you really shouldn't be doing
such crazy shit in the first place.

I also removed Repeat _isCompleted tracking because it didn't make any sense.
At first I thought animation chains were intended to be reused, but that's not
possible. complete() also cancel()s the animations, and once an animation is
cancel()ed, it can never be reused. Moreover, once an animation is cancel()ed,
next() will never be called on it. So there are no circumstances in which
Repeat would need to return something special from next() after it had been
complete()d.
No recursion needed.

Cancelled -> canceled

I really can't decide which spelling I hate less, but I definitely
hate a comment saying one the line above using a variable saying
the other.

Added ability to complete Animation chains instantly

-Completed animations will instantly apply the final result of the
animation, and propagate the completion call to the rest of the
animations in the chain.  Animations which have already been completed
manually or automatically by the animator will have no effect.
-Abstract method for complete() added to Animation (can be called
through the Animation.Handle), and implementations for existing
TriplePlay Animation subclasses

Use assert in lieu of Asserts.

Fix bug where quickly toggling mute on a sound board could NPE.

In particular, if the board has a looping sound (music), the timing of faders could get interleaved such that things were inconsistent.

Comment out an Flump Library Asserts call which is taking a measurable amount of time.

Since PlayN Asserts are not actually in any way removed for production (despite what the documentation would have you believe), having this assert here does noticably ungood things to performance while loading a flump library.

Code like: '"foo " + bar' is implicitly turned into

Make Logger.format() more consistent with other Loggers. (See backwards-incompatibility note)

In particular, this now takes a prefix message so it formats to a string like:
message [key=value, key=value, ...]

Backwards-Incompatibility Note: Due to the varargs parameter on the old version, any old code with at least two arguments expecting the old signature will continue to compile and will produce unexpected results, however it seems like most everything was using it thinking it was the consistent new way anyway.

Scale3Background now supports Horizontal or Vertical alignments.
Track the maximum drag distance for track behavior.
Don't handle null, let it crash.
Convenience method for uniformly positioning widgets.

Make setPosition paint with a dt instead of setting _position

Previously, it would diddle _position itself and then paint with
a zero dt. Everything worked fine for simple movies, but if you had
a Movie which had other Movies on it, they wouldn't advance.

This is still a little bit weird for Movies that contain other Movies
with different durations; as you loop, the two fall in and out of sync,
but that's always been the case. If you're doing complicated movies like
that and then explicitly reaching in and modifying the position yourself,
caveat emptor.

Possibly the answer here is to let you setDuration with negative values?
Since it WILL let you set an arbitrarily overly-large value right now and
loop through N times to reach it. But at that point, maybe you should just
be calling paint() with your calculated dt yourself. I haven't fully thought
it through, so that's left as an excercise for the reader when he or she
decides to go into wacky town like that.

This encompasses the proposed OverlayLayout and probably some other things in puzzle pirates.

Need to actually ship the flump's library.json

Thanks tangxf!
Formatting &c cleanups.
Use handy new horizontal() method.

Fix text widget sizing problem.

The icon sizing needs to start with the text size, it can't be done in the wrong order. So
calculate the usedWidth specially for autoshrinkage.

Removing final property on Scale3#height

since there is no set method available, like in Axis

Fix SWT native font size.
Spurious semicolon.

Don't integrate with AWT or SWT by default.

It causes Eclipse to crash on the Mac and IntelliJ to do weird things.
Make HTML view 800x600.

Colors.darker can now take a custom dark factor.

Because calling Colors.darker(Colors.darker(Colors.darker())) is not good for anyone's health.

Two tiled image background fixes.

- don't try to render unready images; they have zero width/height which results
  in an infinte loop
- restore alpha after we're done rendering
Don't overdraw.

Added tiled image background.

This doesn't use GL image repeating, which requires POT sized image.

Properly auto-shrink during size computation.

Previously we would only auto-shrink once we were already laid out. This meant
that we reported a much larger preferred height than we ended up using, which
caused funky layouts.

Also fixed issue with iconGap not being included in usedWidth/Height in
layout().
Add tween(XYValue). Use it elsewhere.
Removed no longer true comment.
Remove support for removed methods.
Return an IntValue when value-ating an int.

Provide way to pass a singleton effect renderer.

If your effect renderer doesn't require parameters from the element, you can
just do:

  addStyles(Style.TEXT_EFFECT.is(myEffectRenderer))
Remove some deprecated bits.
Use withEffect().
TextStyle.withEffect()
Restore the ability to override creation of the effect renderer on custom text widgets.
Add animation barriers demo/test.

Concatenate alpha when capturing a layer.

Canvas fields are write only so it needs to be passed around. This works in my local app, but
needs testing against alpha != 1 case.

Bring comments up to date with implementation changes.

Also unprotected TouchBars ctor, an oversight.

Create "normal" styles directly.

This avoids the "with" allocation overhead yet reduces boolean parameter clutter.

Updated to use TextStyle and StyledText.
Remove unused override.
Support TEXT_WRAP style in SWT native fields.
@Overrides

Also support refreshing native overlay bounds on SWT.

After some testing on Linux, SWT generates a lot of artifacts if fields are moved around directly,
so post a pending refresh repeatedly to invokeLater until some time has passed.
Update to new playn and calculate the transform and landscape values locally.

Quick and dirty implementation of swt overlay hiding.

This gets rid of ugliness when native fields (or web browsers in yotab) are logically underneath a
popup menu, but is not as nice as the iOS version because SWT doesn't support setting a clipping
region.

Use our own UI overlay for iOS.

This will bring the overlay mechanism more into line with the way the java/swt ones work.
Fix translation when ICON styles change.
Re-render if text is NOT equal.
Oops, save our rendered bits.

Nix TextGlyph, use TextConfig.

This makes "did anything change" comparison sufficiently less cumbersome that
I'm fine with not factoring it out. Plus new "text rendering things" are likely
to end up in TextConfig which means anyone using this same approach will
benefit from them automatically, which was the goal of TextGlyph.

Factored rerender-avoidance into TextGlyph.

We may want to move more of TextWidget's special jigger pokery therein so that
other parties who want to render text outside the purview of a TPUI widget can
benefit from its accumulated cruft^h^h^h^h^hknowledge.

If our text, size, and style info is unchanged, no need to redraw the glyph.

This gives a very significant performance improvement both in not having to do the drawing and not having to allocate the temporary memory in any situation where other layout changes are needing to happen frequently.
Some tidying.

Revamped to make Entity final, pool entities.

Entity is now a reusable container for an int and some bit flags. This
eliminates the "extend Entity and sneak some stuff in your class" approach, but
you can just wrap an Entity in your sneaky class if you really want do to that.

I considered eliminating Entity entirely and just passing around an int, but
the need to box the int to dispatch entityAdded/Changed/etc. signals made me
rethink things. The goal with pooled entities is zero GC during normal
operation, and boxing would thus be a no-no. I could keep the Integer instances
around, but at that point I might as well create my own "box" (aka Entity)
which can also have the "interested systems" and "attached components" bit
masks, along with a few other flags.

This also eliminates the limit on number of systems and components. Yay BitVec.
Select menu items on roll over (for mouse platforms).

Make max systems/components configurable.

I could make it dynamically expand, but it's pretty easy to increase the max if
you ever hit it and it makes things a bit faster/simpler.
Simple asteroids game to demo entity system.

Remove keyboard event post for SWT text fields.

Because the platform uses a global key filter, doing it here is not necessary and causes a double
dispatch.
Use the right tool for the job.
Update content visibility after layout.

Add an example of making a button throb.

This requires too much hackery, so I'm going to do something to make it less
ugly.
Scoot convert method up to the base class.

Redo layout to evenly split weight between columns.

The table layout would do wonky things if one entered a lot of text and put it
into the disabled text widget.
Implement focus.
Set the app name in the demo.
Also convert component color images.

Workaround canvas whiteout issue.

This turns out to be MacOS only (tested on 10.7.5). The workaround is bizarre, I feel lucky to
have stumbled across it. Perhaps the cocoa gl initializes clipping early and does something
special unless a sibling is present.

Fix bug on repeating a PlayMovie animation.

During init, we set the movie to its start. This means when we repeat we put it back there rather than continuing off the end which seems to lead to an infinite loop.
Tweak: do a click immediately if the pointer is newly in bounds.

New behavior for rapid fire buttons.

Also an intermediate Capturing class, which is not really necessary but I could see being useful.
Add a commented out block for the weirdness.
Make sure new ios native fields get styles too.

Move use of SWT platform into a command line switch for now.

Refactor to work with SWT's immutable control style.

Instead of enumerating the kinds of fields that might cause reallocation, just assume reallocation
can occur on any style change. This will work with SWT, makes the ios and "java" versions more
clear, and moves the platform-specific logic of when the mode should really change down into the
paltform, where it belongs. Tada!
Publish the Range's content position.
Less clunky.
Extract a scale9 utility from background.

Fix bugs in TypedStorage.setFor().

Fixes #38, #39.

Prepare for release of 1.7.9c.

Sorry for all the little releases.

Change to requestFocusInWindow

requestFocus has some bad side effects on some platforms.

Upgrade to SBT 0.13.0.

Disabled Proguard stuff. Why do I try to make this stuff work in SBT? I should
really know better than to invite those yaks into the yard.

Fixing issue where contents were displayed offset within the frame.

The entired contents of the window were occassionally being shifted out of the frame. Controls were responding as if the widgets were in their normal position. This was fairly reproducable by running more than one instace of TripleDemoJava at once.
Calling pack() before the JFrame is shown consistently fixes this. According to Oracle, pack() is meant to be called before setVisible(true) anyway. This has only been reported on OSX. This was fairly reproducable by running more than one instace of TripleDemoJava at once.

Back to snapshots.

Revert "Prepare for release of 1.7.9b."

This reverts commit 6dab8cb976923cd1e629cfb5d6227a31520bd11c.
Prepare for release of 1.7.9b.

Pop that request over to AWT.

Side effect here was that about half the time the field did not gain focus. For some reason,
even with the fix it is still short of 100%, failing about 1 in 10 times.
Allow the focused field to be cleared.

Update the native text on the AWT thread.

This was causing a weird side effect. Highlighting the text in a field and typing a new letter
would place the insertion point at the beginning of the field (about 90% of the time, sometimes
it didn't). So if you typed two or more keys, you'd rarely get what you want.

Maybe this will shore us up for a while, but I'm quite worried about the "dual event pump"
situation with AWT and playn fighting. There are other issues like this one, and probably some
crash bugs lurking, waiting for just the right use case.

Back to snapshots.

Clean up unused import.

Listen for and post key events from native text fields.

The game can't catch keypresses and prevent them from making it to the text field, but can respond
easily to non-printables like tab, escape and arrow keys.

Change the keyboard listener to an activity signal for native text fields.

The implementation was a kludge. I'm guessing there's a correct way to do it, but yotab only cares
about the activity and this was created for yotab, so just dispatch that for now. No need to make
it look like a legitimate key dispatch.
Demo the origin style.

Sort out popup position configuration.

This was confusing the concept of trigger point and menu origin. There are some common scenarios,
but you basically want to be able to configure them independently. Now that can be done through
styles. The old "at" methods are deprecated but still supported by manipluating a couple of lazily
created members.

To convert to the new system, addStyles on the trigger and menu and be sure and pass the pointer
event to the Pop constructor.
Added TODO comment.

Allow text effect renderers to have an offsetX/Y

This means that the effect renderer can do things like draw a shadow below the text without causing the primary front text to be offset compared to other text with a more basic renderer.

Make a way to deploy locally.

This just means it's easy to manage a maven repository manually
using maven command line options.
Consider focus loss a cancellation of editing.
Break out the creation of TextWidget effect renderer so it can be overridden.

It turns out fingers are fat and inaccurate. This also bumps up the non-touch case from 0 to 5.

It's really not bad to "new Glyph(layer)" instead of
"new Glyph()", and having this extra class gets obnoxiously in the way

Dex demands this class be public.

It's unarguably weird to have a non-public class in the inheritance hierarchy
of a bunch of public classes, but the JVM doesn't really care. Dalvik on the
other hand gets pissy. So we won't do that.
Allow a Pop reference to be retained and used to force cancel a menu.
Allow the library MoviePlayer is drawing from to be set.

Alternative fix for clicks on text fields not working.

The problem with making the canvas not focusable is that it totally breaks PlayN keyboard. Oops!

So instead, manually detect when the canvas is eating a click and issue a focus request on the hit
component.

I also decided to bottleneck the overlays through the platform rather than exposing the JFrame,
which was sort of on the cards anyway, though not technically needed for this.

Don't give the frame a dumb title.

It looks better if it stays blank until the game code can set it properly.

Stop resolving style willy-nilly.

Instead, stash the result during layout, as is customary.

Add a BinaryFlumpLoader in the spirit of the JsonLoader, but from a binary format.

The LibraryData class captures that binary format and provides the mechanisms for converting back and forth between Json and the binary. The ConvertFlumpLibsToBinary tool can be executed to convert existing library.json files into library.bin files.
Added toString for Insets.
Unused imports

Use new JsonLoader.loadLibrary method.

Factored loading out of runtime object model.

JsonLoader is now the only thing that knows/cares about JSON, and parties that
wish to make use of a binary format can simply follow its lead and construct
the runtime object model directly.
Updated Elements in some comments.

Actually, only do that the first time.

No need to keep preparing over and over and over.
Also prepare the underlying Sound when preparing a LazySound
Make all transitions clamp their interped values.

Added hacky mechanism to skip transition frames.

As the wordy comment indicates, this is a simple way to "fix" the jerkiness
caused by a screen loading up a bunch of images in wasAdded(). The loading is
not long enough to merit making a big deal out of it with a loading screen or
something, like it's 100ms, but 100ms causes a big jerk when you're normally
expecting animation frames to arrive every 15ms.

A "proper" solution is to load images asynchronously and then only start
rendering once they're loaded (though then you still have the delay caused by
uploading textures to the GPU on the first frame), but that complicates the
shit out of client code with a bunch of image callbacks and blah blah blah, and
Java provides no good programming language constructs to keep that from
overwhelming your otherwise simple UI initialization code with boilerplate and
callback spaghetti.

Throw the MFE rather than using trigger.

As I've expounded upon elsewhere, throwing different types of exception
depending on how many things fail is a fiasco for the catcher. Always throwing
the MFE is simpler across the board.
Added remove().
Avoid freakout if a root is doubly removed/destroyed.

Introducing ImageOverlay.

This isn't all that useful by itself, but the plan is to use this to implement Menu without all
the hacky clipping etc.

Method to remove an element from its parent, if possible

This is to cover the fairly frequent use case in yotab where a nested UI is constructed, the
intermediate nests are not retained, an "egg" part such as a button is retained, and later on the
controlling entity wants to remove that egg from the nest.

Use a combined XYValue for Animation.Two.

We need PER_VERT_ATTRS here as well.

Beavis says "Heh heh, pervert attrs!"

We can now use the stock PlayN shader, pretty much.

Fixes #36.

Now that it supports tinting (more correctly than we did), it does everything
we need it to do. I had to rearrange it to ensure that all stable (same for all
verts in a quad) attributes were contiguous. Now that it is, we can splat all
of our per-particle data in a single copy, then add our vert+tex coords.

This fixes Evgeni's issue where tinting was causing weird edge artifacts.
Move more child management methods up to Container.
Added Insets.adjust().

Respect movie.speed().

This doesn't behave precisely the same as the paint()-based solution in Movie itself; if the speed is changed halfway through an animation, the effect will be retroactive using PlayMovie, but not so otherwise. This may or may not be a big deal.
Meh, I'd like to fix all this but not now.
Use Font.derive().
CONSTRAIN means to available width, not max width.

Added auto-shrink mechanism.

This causes a TextWidget to drop its font size until it fits into its allotted
horizontal space. Useful when wrapping is not an option.
Allow a flicker to be disabled.

Allow a constraint to adjust a widget's hints.

This ensures that if we know a label will, for example, be fixed to width W
that we don't pass some actual width that's way bigger than W, but rather we
pass W and let the label know that it needs to wrap within that width.
Also allow destroying Container elements
Make Flump instances destroyable.

Allow min/max to be mutated.

It's not unreasonable for the range of a flicker to change, and none of the
internal flicker math depends on fixed min/max. Indeed, its internal physics
responds pretty reasonably to bounds changes, even when they result in
situations where you are temporarily scrolled way past either end.
Break user-initiated selection into overridable method.
Beans/frank.
Improve behavior when source image is smaller than bg space.

Handle unready-image icon passed to ctor.

Prior to this, it was not triggering the addition of a Callback to the icon to
be notified when the image was ready.

Added a button that uses images for up/down state.

I'm not super thrilled with this because it can't extend Button and it's a
little annoying to have two different kinds of buttons in your code for code
that wants to operate indiscriminately on button like things.

Clickable doesn't really help because you want something that has Element's API
(setVisible, setEnabled) and Button's API (click, onClick, etc.).

It's also annoying to duplicate a non-trivial amount of code from Button. If I
had traits with self types, I could do all this properly. Or union types. Or
pink unicorns. Pink unicorns solve all problems.
Be good and leave a deprecated ClickableTextWidget.
Bring SBT build up to date with various changes.
Split assets into separate submodule.
Move back to snapshot PlayN.

Fix a bug where the window size was larger than requested on some platforms/themes.

Fancier Windows Vista/7 themes change the size of the window borders based on resizability of the window so we need pack() to happen last.

[maven-release-plugin] prepare release tripleplay-1.7.2
Added bindEnabled().

Complain loudly if a null Animation is added to an AnimGroup

Raise an IllegalArgumentException if an attempt is made to add a null to an AnimGroup.  Without this, a NullPointerException is thrown downstream with no ability to locate the offending code.
Added bindText + bindIcon for fluent construction.

Added TextConfig.renderCX for rendering text centered on an x.

This is otherwise complicated by the need to remember to incorporate the text
effect when calculating the width for centering. Should probably add a
renderCY() and renderCXY() for completeness. Or accept alignment constants.
Meh.
Remove the native field when the field is hidden.

Call showNewScreen() before initting transitor.

Otherwise showNewScreen() changes the translation of the screen after the
transitor positions it in init() which causes one frame of jank for transitions
that require the new screen to start at non-zero coordinates.

Added support tinting Scale9Backgrounds.

The Scale9Background now sports a setTint() method allowing for the recoloring of a scaled background.  Tinting only works on GL-based backends and, like other setTint() methods, resets alpha.

Make our resolvers work on inty and floaty types.

Because menus deselect their items on close, layout occurs a moment after the item trigger, which
